#summary XML/Object Binding and Object Persistence: XStream + XBird= !
#labels Phase-Implementation,Featured

= Introduction =

XBird introduces an object persistence feature. It supports querying capabilities to persistence objects with the full XQuery expressibility.

The feature uses [http://xstream.codehaus.org/persistence-tutorial.html XStream persistence API] to serialize a Java object into XML instead of a binary format, and then use a native XML database, i.e., XBird, to persist the objects.ã€€
It is easy since XStream avoids tedious configuration through [http://xstream.codehaus.org/annotations-tutorial.html annotation] or [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convention_over_Configuration Convention Over Configuration].

= Requirements =

In addition to [http://code.google.com/p/xbird/wiki/LibraryDependencyListing the minimum requirements] for xbird/open, the X/O binding feature requires the following libraries in _classpath_ to serialize/deserialize objects:
   
   * lib/optional/[http://code.google.com/p/xbird/source/browse/#svn/trunk/xbird-open/lib/optional xstream-xx.jar] - [http://xstream.codehaus.org/ XStream] is a simple library to serialize objects to XML and back again.
   * lib/optional/[http://code.google.com/p/xbird/source/browse/#svn/trunk/xbird-open/lib/optional xpp3_min-xx.jar] - [http://www.extreme.indiana.edu/xgws/xsoap/xpp/mxp1/index.html XPP] is a fast XML pull-parser implementation required by XStream.

= Coding Guideline =

=== Persisting objects to Database ===

[http://xstream.codehaus.org/javadoc/index.html XStream persistence API] provides persistent [http://xstream.codehaus.org/javadoc/com/thoughtworks/xstream/persistence/XmlArrayList.html List]/[http://xstream.codehaus.org/javadoc/com/thoughtworks/xstream/persistence/XmlMap.html Map]/[http://xstream.codehaus.org/javadoc/com/thoughtworks/xstream/persistence/XmlSet.html Set] to keep track of persistence data.

Here is an example to persist objects using [http://xstream.codehaus.org/javadoc/com/thoughtworks/xstream/persistence/XmlArrayList.html XmlArrayList]:
{{{
XStream xstream = XBirdCollectionStrategy.getAnnotationProcessableXStreamInstance();
XBirdCollectionStrategy strategy = new XBirdCollectionStrategy(COLLECTION_NAME, xstream);

List author1 = Arrays.asList(new Author("anonymous"));
RendezvousMessage msg1 = new RendezvousMessage(15, author1);
System.out.println(xstream.toXML(msg1));
 
List author2 = Arrays.asList(new Author("makoto"), new Author("leo"), new Author("grun"));
RendezvousMessage msg2 = new RendezvousMessage(15, author2, "firstPart", "secondPart");
System.out.println(xstream.toXML(msg2));
 
List list = new XmlArrayList(strategy);
list.add(msg1);
list.add(msg2);
}}}
The definition of `Author` class and `RendezvousMessage` class can be found in  [http://code.google.com/p/xbird/source/browse/trunk/xbird-open/main/test/java/xbird/ext/xstream/XBirdCollectionStrategyTest.java XBirdCollectionStrategyTest class].

The output will be as follows:
{{{
# The first element in list is stored as "1.xml" in the specified collection.
<message>
  <author>
    <name>anonymous</name>
  </author>
  <content class="java.util.Arrays$ArrayList">
    <a class="string-array"/>
  </content>
  <created>1217087568161</created>
</message>
}}}
{{{
# The second element in list is stored as "2.xml" in the specified collection.
<message>
  <author>
    <name>makoto</name>
  </author>
  <author>
    <name>leo</name>
  </author>
  <author>
    <name>grun</name>
  </author>
  <content class="java.util.Arrays$ArrayList">
    <a class="string-array">
      <string>firstPart</string>
      <string>secondPart</string>
    </a>
  </content>
  <created>1217087568163</created>
</message>
}}}

=== Retrieving objects from Database ===

Querying over persistent documents and retrieving the result sequence is capable as follows:
{{{
String query1 = "fn:collection('/" + COLLECTION_NAME + "/.*.xml')//author";
XQueryProcessor proc = new XQueryProcessor();
XQueryModule compiled1 = proc.parse(query1);
Sequence items = proc.execute(compiled1);
INodeSequence nodes = ProxyNodeSequence.wrap(items, DynamicContext.DUMMY);

for(DTMElement node : nodes) {
   Object unmarshalled = xstream.unmarshal(new DTMReader(node));
   Author author = (Author) unmarshalled;
   System.out.println("author: " + author.getName());
}
}}}

As you can see the above example, the partial object can be obtainable in addition to the entire object.  

_Note that you can define the serialized XML format through [http://xstream.codehaus.org/annotations-tutorial.html annotations] in XStream. Hence, you can query it!_

The output of the above example will be as follows: 
{{{
author: makoto
author: leo
author: grun
author: anonymous
}}}
